description: Variant of sipe, from Middle English *sipen, from Old English sipian, from Proto-Germanic *sipōną, derivative of *sīpaną (compare Middle Dutch sīpen (“to drip”), German Low German siepern (“to seep”), archaic German seifen (“to trickle blood”)), from Proto-Indo-European *seyb-, *sib- (“to pour out, drip, trickle”) (compare Latin sēbum (“suet, tallow”), Ancient Greek εἴβω (eíbō, “to drop, drip”)). See soap.

entries.meaning: A small spring, pool, or other spot where liquid from the ground (e.g. water, petroleum or tar) has oozed to the surface; a place of seeping.
Moisture, liquid, gas, etc. that seeps out; a seepage.
The seeping away of a liquid, etc.

verbs.description: seep (third-person singular simple present seeps, present participle seeping, simple past and past participle seeped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To ooze or pass slowly through pores or other small openings, and in overly small quantities; said of liquids, etc.
examples: Water has seeped through the roof.
The water steadily seeped in through the thirl.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To enter or penetrate slowly; to spread or diffuse.
examples: Woe seeped through her heart thinking of what had befallen their ethnic group.
Fear began to seep into the local community over the contamination of their fishpond.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To diminish or wane away slowly.
examples: The resistance movement against the invaders had slowly  seeped away.

entries.meaning: (transitive) (of a crack etc.) To allow a liquid to pass through, to leak.
